item.title: Getting started with LAMMPS
item.description:
What is LAMMPS?
LAMMPS is a classical molecular dynamics code with a focus on materials modeling. It’s an acronym for Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator.
LAMMPS has potentials for solid-state materials (metals, semiconductors) and soft matter (biomolecules, polymers) and coarse-grained or mesoscopic systems. It can be used to
item.author:

item.title: Practical Guide To Not Blocking The Event Loop
item.description: JavaScript runs in a single-threaded environment with an event loop, an architecture that is very easy to reason about. It's a continuous loop executing incoming work. Synchronous work runs immediately; asynchronous work runs when there is no synchronous work to left to perform. This design implies that performing synchronous work is a Big Deal: for every continuous moment that it runs, the event loop cannot perform any work -- none!
item.author: (:: Slava Knyazev)

item.title: Error handling patterns
item.description: Error handling is a fundamental aspect of programming. Unless you are writing “hello world”, you will need to handle errors in your code. In this post, I will discuss a bit the most common approaches used by various programming languages. Return error codes This is one of the most ancient strategies - if a function can fail, it can simply return an error code - often a negative number, or null.

item.title: The Curse of Performative User Studies
item.description: Anyone who has spent enough time publishing some kind of artistic tools in computer graphics—even in computer vision conferences—has probably gotten reviews that praised a paper’s ideas and results, but required a user study. Or the reviewers didn’t like the paper’s methods or results, but still said the authors should add a user study. And so, maybe you added user studies to your next paper solely because you believed reviewers would require it.
item.author: (AaronHertzmann)
